title: Curse of Star Baker strikes Great British Bake Off final: David wins
text:
The curse of Star Baker struck again in the final of The Great British Bake Off.

Even a fortnight ago it was hard to see how the bookies’ odds-on favourite could lose. Steph Blackwell had been vying to become the first contestant in the history of the show to be Star Baker four weeks running.

She narrowly missed out (due to Henry) but when she promptly won it for her fourth time in the next episode, it meant only one person in the ten series of GBBO had been awarded Star Baker more than she had.

Well done: David Atherton became the first Great British Bake Off champion who had never been Star Baker on Tuesday evening

In 2015 Richard Burr had been Star Baker five times but only come third. But like Richard and so many leading contenders, Steph failed to win the big one – and in spectacular fashion too with two of the three Challenges proving calamitous.

So her early successes counted for nothing. In fact, statistically, the ‘honour’ counted against her.

Only once in nine years had the contestant who’d been Star Baker more times than any of their rivals then gone on to be champion: Candice Brown, in 2017.

Hopes dashed: The curse of Star Baker struck again in the final of The Great British Bake Off as show favourite Steph Blackwell lost out to winner David

Nearly all the ‘best’ Bakers during the other series (like Ruby Tandoh, James Morton, or Steven Carter-Bailey) were destined/doomed to finish as Runners-Up, losing out to someone with a couple of titles at most (such as Sophie Faldo or Rahul Mandal).

Four of the eventual winners had been Star Baker only once, which meant in eight of the nine weeks someone else had been superior.

David Atherton went one better, becoming the first GBBO champion who had never been Star Baker.

So he had a fair point when he declared at the start:

‘I’m definitely the underdog!’

Victor: There’s no doubt David deserved to win but was also helped by his opponents, particularly Steph who cracked/collapsed under pressure

There’s no doubt he deserved to win but was also helped by his opponents, particularly Steph who cracked/collapsed under pressure.

Alice did far better (particularly in the Showstopper) but lost out to David in the Technical round when her ‘twice-baked Stilton soufflés’ were, in the words of Paul Hollywood, ‘too gluey.’

And as he said tried her chocolate cake in the Signature Challenge: ‘I’m lacking the chocolate.’

A real case of: you had one job….

Nearly, but not quite: Alice did far better (particularly in the Showstopper) but lost out to David in the Technical round

... when her ‘twice-baked Stilton soufflés’ were, in the words of Paul Hollywood, ‘too gluey'

For reasons best known to herself she had made a chocolate cake that tasted of pears, maple cream cheese, and ginger.

‘It’s a bit wobbly and clumsy,’ tutted Prue too.

As usual, it all came down to Showstopper – ‘a deliciously deceptive picnic’ where the Bakers’ creations had to look like something else.

‘They could make a bread roll look like a pork pie,’ Hollywood explained, for example. ‘Or a cake that looks like a banana.’

‘Yuck!’ you thought, or more precisely: ‘why?’

Hollywood hailed David’s picnic as ‘amazing’, ‘stunning’, and ‘very clever.’

Unusual: For reasons best known to herself she had made a chocolate cake that tasted of pears, maple cream cheese, and ginger

Not convinced: ‘It’s a bit wobbly and clumsy,’ tutted Prue as she observed her creation

His fig rolls resembled sausage rolls (not much of a stretch admittedly) while his ‘cheese’ was actually cake with orange fondant.

‘Bravo!’ cheered Prue Leith.

The theme proved salt in the wound for Alice, whose parents were in danger of missing the final’s special picnic when their flight was cancelled.

Every time Sandi Toksvig checked for an update on their progress, Alice started sobbing.

’It’s my worst nightmare really. The biggest day of my life and everything! I couldn’t imagine it without them.’

Here we go: As usual, it all came down to Showstopper – ‘a deliciously deceptive picnic’ where the Bakers’ creations had to look like something else

Interesting: ‘They could make a bread roll look like a pork pie,’ Hollywood explained. ‘Or a cake that looks like a banana'

She bravely battled on making pork pies, chicken drumsticks, and Scotch eggs out of carrot cake that Paul Hollywood said were delicious but really didn’t look it.

As for the favourite going into the final, Steph had been in the lead after the first round.

But you feared the worst at the start of the programme when the three contestants had an X Factor-style VT (to fill up the time).

For ten weeks we hadn’t known much about the Bakers (even their surnames) so it seemed a bit later now, particularly with the picture Steph’s family painted.

‘She was not in a good place this time last year - not knowing what to do with her life,’ her mum said. ‘If people could see how far she’s come as a person, they wouldn’t believe it.’

Gutted: The theme proved salt in the wound for Alice, whose parents were in danger of missing the final’s special picnic when their flight was cancelled

Sad: ’It’s my worst nightmare really. The biggest day of my life and everything! I couldn’t imagine it without them,' she said

Nonetheless they seemed to suggest Steph had a track record of cracking under pressure – literally in her younger days as a runner.

‘She’s got it all and she doesn’t think she’s got anything’ her step grandmother concluded, helpfully.

Like a self-fulfilling prophecy, or as if they’d virtually, psychically, got into Steph’s head, while she was mixing her mixture for the first cake, she told Sandi Toksvig her nerves were ‘jangling.’

‘I used to get like this in athletics as well. I was always nervous that I was going to hit the last hurdle.’

Not the best association.

Well ahead: As for the favourite going into the final, Steph had been in the lead after the first round

Awkward: But in the Technical Challenge, she made the fatal mistake of using cold water for her bain marie and started panicking

In the Technical Challenge, she made the fatal mistake of using cold water for her bain marie and started panicking.

‘I just feel a bit stupid!’ she said tearfully (to herself). ‘Oh dear, pray for me! Do I keep going? What a disaster!’

She wasn’t wrong.

‘It’s like eating sauce,’ concluded Prue, sympathetically, while her colleague complained: ‘the biscuits are too thick.’

Poor Paul.

Waterworks: ‘I just feel a bit stupid!’ she said tearfully (to herself). ‘Oh dear, pray for me! Do I keep going? What a disaster!’

Blunt assessment: ‘It’s like eating sauce,’ concluded Prue, sympathetically

Steph was such a mess, Noel Fielding gave her a pep talk, reminding her: ‘you’ve won Star Baker four times’ – which we know now didn’t help.

‘Come on! You’ve got this!’ he added, which people only say when you haven’t.

Sure enough Steph’s Showstopper wasn’t any better.

‘It’s so dry. It’s just SO bad, all of it!’ she muttered again trying not to cry as her cakes got stuck. ‘I don’t know how I can get through it.’

Using an electric whisk to whip up her buttercream, when she lost her grip (on the bowl – and probably generally), she nearly whisked her fingers off.

Supportive: Steph was such a mess, Noel Fielding gave her a pep talk, reminding her: ‘you’ve won Star Baker four times’ – which we know now didn’t help

‘There’s obviously been a few issues today,’ Hollywood said judging her ‘illusion picnic’, complaining her macaroons looked ‘nothing like strawberries’ (because they didn’t ‘glisten’) and her giant burger bun cake ‘hasn’t got much flavor to it. It’s a little bit over-baked as well,’ he added for good measure. ‘Never mind Steph.’

He had made her Star Baker in nearly half the episodes of this series but didn’t sound particularly bothered.

Steph was so upset he felt compelled to give her a hug.

That’s when you knew for sure she was doomed.

Triumphant: David got a hug from Paul after winning Tuesday evening's final
description: Steph Blackwell had been vying to become the first contestant in the history of the show to be Star Baker four weeks running.
